Title: Large frugivorous birds facilitate functional connectivity of fragmented landscapes
ScaleNotes: 1 study site (Oribi Gorge Nature Reserve), but doesn't say how big it is. I am considering "patch" as a plot, but patch size is variable (min = 0.0016 km2, max = 74.29 km2, mean = 2.16 km2) and was drawn after seeing where birds went. There were 103 total patches deliniated.
GenInfo: Monitored flight pathways of frugivores to track seed dispersal across different habitat types using remote sensing data (for habitat types) and male bird daytime migrations using GPS (mist netted bird, banded with GPS units to record location every 15min), downloaded GPS data via VHF receivers. Study in South Africa. Tracked 30 birds (9 in breeding season, 21 in non-breeding season) for 543 days
gen_methods_notes: Monitored flight pathways of frugivores to track seed dispersal across different habitat types using remote sensing data (for habitat types) and male bird daytime migrations using GPS (mist netted bird, banded with GPS units to record location every 15min), downloaded GPS data via VHF receivers. Title: Mapping ecosystem services in New York City: Applying a social-ecological approach in urban vacant land
ScaleNotes: said they sampled 5% of the 1502 vacant lots in all 5 boroughs of NYC so 75 lots but reported Ns in tables as 1502; didn't give size of lots/size of area monitored within each lot (so assume they looked at entire lot)

Title: Mapping social-ecological vulnerability to inform local decision making
ScaleNotes: Wall-to-wall map produced for all of French Moorea, at 5m pixel res, but doesn't say how big French Moorea is. Modeled ecological resilience of fisheries at 57 points with fish count data, then used boosted regression tree to extrapolate across all of French Moorea. They considered distance (2km radius) from fishing house in their model so to me that gets at connectivity a bit, but unit of analysis is planning unit (municipality for social vulnerability, n = 5; habitat type for ecological vulnerability, n = 6).. don't state size of municipalities or hab types..
GenInfo: Used a previously published model from the lead author to model fishing effort and ecological exposure around Moorea, collected data on spatially explicit indicators in a 6-month window, and used census data for social component
gen_methods_notes: Used a previously published model from the lead author to model fishing effort and ecological exposure around Moorea, collected data on spatially explicit indicators in a 6-month window, and used census data for social component

Title: Optimizing intermediate ecosystem services in agriculture using rules based on landscape composition and configuration indices
ScaleNotes: These are hypothetical matrix data where the matrix consistent of larger farms (sites, N) and rows x columns of fields within each farm (n x n fields). For the study, authors chose 35 farms (sites) and  each farm is comprised of 5x5 fields (25 "plots" per site). No hypothetical area noted for size of sites and fields (not relevant to data exercise).
GenInfo: Study does not take place in any location. Is a hypothetical/conceptual modeling example. Researchers based in Denmark.
gen_methods_notes: Study does not take place in any location. Is a hypothetical/conceptual modeling example. Researchers based in Denmark.

Title: Organic farming and host density affect parasitism rates of tortricid moths in vineyards
ScaleNotes: Sampling occurred across 79 vineyards; they sampled 100 plants at each over an unknown area (no real 'plots')

Title: Organic farming promotes biotic resistance to foodborne human pathogens
ScaleNotes: Measured feces removal in broccoli crop rows per farm site, but doesn't say how many rows treated with sentinel feces. One pit trap used per farm site, so assume 1 "plot" per site. 70 farm sites in study total. Doesn't specify area of farms or crop area studied at each farm.
GenInfo: Surveyed above and below ground beetle communities at 70 farm sites along US West Coast (WA, OR and CA), paired with complementary lab microcosm experiments to measure pig feces removal rates by beetles collected with organic farm sites vs. conventional farm sites. Can't find how many feces removal microcosm reps used. 4 reps per farm soil treatment (16 farms?) for soil community (bacterial diversity) microcosm experiment. Data collected over two years, but they do not model effect of time (it's more they needed that amount of time to sample all of their sites). Use a geospatial data layer to quantify land cover type (e.g. wetland, grassland, etc.) surrounding each farm.
gen_methods_notes: Surveyed above and below ground beetle communities at 70 farm sites along US West Coast (WA, OR and CA), paired with complementary lab microcosm experiments to measure pig feces removal rates by beetles collected with organic farm sites vs. conventional farm sites. Can't find how many feces removal microcosm reps used. 4 reps per farm soil treatment (16 farms?) for soil community (bacterial diversity) microcosm experiment. Data collected over two years, but they do not model effect of time (it's more they needed that amount of time to sample all of their sites). Use a geospatial data layer to quantify land cover type (e.g. wetland, grassland, etc.) surrounding each farm.

Title: Reconciling community ecology and ecosystem services: Cultural services and benefits from birds in South African National Parks

For Q10, some models included park identity as a spatial variable, but this did not reflect connectivity across sites (e.g., closer vs nearer sites)
GenInfo: I said 'no' to time, because although they mentioned that surveys were carried out over time to capture different birds in different seasons, I do not see this being incorporated into models

gen_methods_notes: Used abundance and biomass data on different reef and lagoon species before, during, and after a few disturbances to parameterize ecosystem network analysis models

Title: Recreational demand for clean water: evidence from geotagged photographs by visitors to lakes

Title: Stream corridors as indicators of watershed land use: A case study in Istanbul
ScaleNotes: 3 watersheds (sites). 66 sub-watersheds (plots). Watershed area provided, but without units

Title: The ecological adaptability of Phragmites australis to interactive effects of water level and salt stress in the Yellow River Delta
ScaleNotes: 48 plant plots (plot) at one experimental site (site)

Title: Trait-based approaches for guiding the restoration of degraded agricultural landscapes in East Africa
ScaleNotes: 5 landscapes = sites, "n=640 observations per site", "745 plots"
GenInfo: five landscapes in 3 African countries studied for extent of soil erosion, vegetation cover and biomass, functional properties of the woody vegetation, and topsoil chemistry
gen_methods_notes: five landscapes in 3 African countries studied for extent of soil erosion, vegetation cover and biomass, functional properties of the woody vegetation, and topsoil chemistry

Title: Uncovering the spatial dynamics of wild rice lakes, harvesters and management across Great Lakes landscapes for shared regional conservation
ScaleNotes: Lake and watershed scale, at least >1200 lakes and >300 watersheds in MN and WI. Large scale but unclear what size the lakes are. Watershed info: Wild rice, with an affinity for flowing water, is most often associated with streams and lakes on flowages, systems that are commonly managed using watershed approaches.
GenInfo: We report three primary analyses: (1) Regional characteristics: geospatial analysis of the relationships between wild rice lakes, management regimes and wild rice harvest across the study region; (2) Patterns of harvest: analysis of harvester use and spatial rela- tionships to wild rice lakes through case studies, landing site visits and in-depth interviews; (3) Decision making regarding the open- ing of harvest: visits with managers and committees.
gen_methods_notes: We report three primary analyses: (1) Regional characteristics: geospatial analysis of the relationships between wild rice lakes, management regimes and wild rice harvest across the study region; (2) Patterns of harvest: analysis of harvester use and spatial rela- tionships to wild rice lakes through case studies, landing site visits and in-depth interviews; (3) Decision making regarding the open- ing of harvest: visits with managers and committees.
